title: Build a Full-Stack Application with Cassandra and React
description:
Join DataStax Devs live as we connect with React.js, build and execute queries on top of the powerful NoSQL database Apache Cassandra via Rest in this 30 minute, hands-on Workshop with our developers. 

REGISTER FOR ASTRA
https://www.datastax.com/lp/astra-registration

ðŸ’¬ DISCORD - chat, questions
https://dtsx.io/discord

ðŸ“… UPCOMING EVENTS
https://www.datastax.com/workshops

ðŸš€ ðŸš€ ENJOY !! ðŸš€ ðŸš€

essentially it is a no sequel distributed database that's designed to be big data ready distributed it's it's built to um you know to handle both read and write performance um as it scales linearly um and what linear scalability means is um you know if you establish that you know you excuse me that you can get a certain level of throughput with like say you know 15 nodes in a cluster that you know that if you need to double your throughput you need to you need to double the number of nodes in the cluster and that'll scale in nearly there won't be any any loss there or any um you know any other any other well there was another word I was thinking about for loss but I I can't come to it right now but anyway so that kind of makes scaling a little bit easier at least Computing out the amount of resources you need um Cassandra approaches the uh the high availability eventual consistency Paradigm for data um it's also you know um has a little little degree of uh self-healing as well so that if a node goes down um the neighboring nodes will actually kind of maintain um any rights that that came in and um you know kind of help that node recover its consistency once it comes back up probably my favorite thing about Cassandra the thing that I feel it really does the best is uh geographic distribution you know you can um you can deploy Cassandra to a data center like on the east coast and on the west coast and maybe Central Europe and you can do a right to any one of those and it'll replicate that right around all three data centers that way your rights can happen anywhere yet your Cassandra well essentially
it is a no sequel distributed database
that's designed to be big data ready
distributed it's it's built to um you
know to handle both read and write
performance
um as it scales linearly
um and what linear scalability means is
um you know if you establish that you
know you excuse me
that you can get a certain level of
throughput with like say you know 15
nodes in a cluster that you know that if
you need to double your throughput you
need to you need to double the number of
nodes in the cluster and that'll scale
in nearly there won't be any any loss
there or any um you know any other any
other well there was another word I was

kind of makes scaling a little bit
easier at least Computing out the amount
of resources you need
um Cassandra approaches the uh the high
availability eventual consistency
Paradigm for data
um it's also you know um has a little
little degree of uh self-healing as well
so that if a node goes down
um the neighboring nodes will actually
kind of maintain
um any rights that that came in and um
you know kind of help that node recover
its consistency once it comes back up
probably my favorite thing about
Cassandra the thing that I feel it
really does the best is uh geographic
distribution you know you can um you can
deploy Cassandra to a data center like
on the east coast and on the west coast
and maybe Central Europe and you can do
a right to any one of those and it'll
replicate that right around all three
data centers that way your rights can
happen anywhere yet your reads are
localized and preventing your customers
or your users from having to jump across
the pond to um to hit a data center so
and of course Cassandra is platform and
vendor independent
um you know you can run it on you know
